headline: Zscaler CEO talks Q1 earnings, cybersecurity, CFO retirement
summary: Cloud cybersecurity developer Zscaler (ZS) outdid estimates for its fiscal first quarter, posting revenue of $627.96 million and adjusted earnings per share (EPS) of $0.77, while underwhelming on its second quarter guidance. Zscaler also announced the retirement of its CFO Remo Canessa. To speak more about the earnings print, Zscaler CEO Jay Chaudhry joins Market Domination Overtime. "The market remains tight, there is scrutiny on large deals. But if you do two things, CIOs will want to work with you: Number one, good cyber security with zero trust architecture, because the firewall-based, VPN-based security is no longer working," Chaudhry underlines, while noting the company's record free cash flow margin. "But along with cyber, if you can tell the CIO that I can take some cost out and save money, you can get the deals done and you can deliver good numbers. That's how Zscaler has done business." Chaudhry also comments on Canessa's retirement, who will stay on as CFO until a successor for the role is selected. To watch more expert insights and analysis on the latest market action, check out more Market Domination Overtime here. This post was written by Luke Carberry Mogan.

headline: High Growth Tech And 2 Other Exciting Stocks with Potential Expansion
summary: As global markets navigate a complex landscape marked by record highs in key U.S. indices and mixed economic signals, investors are keenly observing sectors with potential for robust growth. In this environment, identifying promising stocks involves considering companies that demonstrate resilience and adaptability, particularly those in high-growth tech sectors poised to leverage current market dynamics for expansion.

headline: US Growth Companies With High Insider Ownership In October 2024
summary: As the U.S. stock market experiences fluctuations, with major indexes like the S&P 500 and Dow Jones Industrial Average sliding due to declines in technology and energy stocks, investors are keenly observing economic indicators and corporate earnings for signs of stability. In this environment, growth companies with high insider ownership can be appealing as they often indicate confidence from those closest to the business in its long-term potential amidst market volatility.
